key_points: DUTCH ROLL Basically speaking, Dutch roll is a series of out-of-phase turns, when the aircraft rolls in one direction and yaws in the other
When the yaw is introduced, the strong “dihedral effect” will roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into wind
The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations
learning.explanation: DUTCH ROLL Basically speaking, Dutch roll is a series of out-of-phase turns, when the aircraft rolls in one direction and yaws in the other. When the yaw is introduced, the strong “dihedral effect” will roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability.

The tail plane and elevators act as a horizontal stabilizer and the degree of positive longitudinal static stability that they provide is dependent on the size of the restoring moment they can attain; nevertheless, they do make the largest contribution to the longitudinal static stability
learning.explanation: The longitudinal static stability of an airplane is its ability to return to its original pitch attitude with no outside assistance, after the disturbance that caused a nose-up or a nose-down movement has ceased. The main factors that affect the longitudinal static stability are the design of the tail plane and the position of the CG relative to the position of the CP because they determine the direction of the additional wing-pitching moment. The tail plane and elevators act as a horizontal stabilizer and the degree of positive longitudinal static stability that they provide is dependent on the size of the restoring moment they can attain; nevertheless, they do make the largest contribution to the longitudinal static stability. The tail plane design and the length of the moment arm from the tail plane CP to the CG condition the magnitude of the restoring moment. The effect that the fuselage, and to a lesser extent wing-mounted the engine nacelles, has on the airplane’s longitudinal static stability is normally a destabilizing influence, a negative contribution. If the fuselage aerodynamic center is ahead of the wing aerodynamic center, the aerodynamic center of the wing–fuselage combination is further forward than it would normally be. If such is the case the aircraft CG will be further aft than is normal and the aircraft longitudinal static stability is decreased.

learning.explanation: Dutch Roll Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is undesirable because of the oscillatory nature. Dutch roll can occur when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc.) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc.) Asymmetric shockwaves Modern transport jet aircraft tend to cruise at high altitudes with high Mach numbers, very close to - or just inside - the transonic regime. This is the range of speeds (At and above MCRIT) where some of the aircraft experiences supersonic airflow, but not all the aircraft does. This brings rise to shockwaves, first on the upper wing surfaces near the roots, then spreading to other areas of the aircraft. Shockwaves produce quite high drag forces, classed as "wave drag". If the shockwaves form asymmetrically on the aircraft, whether due to different airflow patterns over the wings, small differences in the aircraft structure, control surfaces, etc., then the different drag forces can cause a yawing motion, which sets off the oscillation known as Dutch roll. This Dutch roll would be made worse by the shockwaves forming on the faster wing, reducing lift and increasing drag to drop it down and drag it back, exacerbating the Dutch roll.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”
The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves aft, the stick force gradient decreases with decreasing maneuvering stability and the lower limit of stick force gradient may be reached. The aft limit, which for safety reasons on a transport airplane is always forward of the neutral point, is confined by insufficient stick-force stability and/or excessive in-flight maneuverability. The minimum stick force per ‘g’ for the maximum permitted load factor, which is 2.5 for large transport airplanes, determines the aft limit of the CG envelope. This means that with a more aft CG, a smaller force is required to achieve a given load factor. If the CG is more aft than anticipated and a force is applied with the same magnitude, the limit load factor may be exceeded.

key_points: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis

Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range
For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC)
learning.explanation: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis. Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range. For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC). There are two moments to consider: the wing moment and the tail moment. The wing moment is a function of the change in wing lift multiplied by arm ‘x’. The tail moment is a function of the change in tailplane lift multiplied by arm ‘y’. The length of both arms is dependent upon CG position. If the CG is considered in a more forward position, the tail arm is larger and the wing arm is smaller. A more forward CG position increases static longitudinal stability. If the nose-down (negative) tail moment is greater than the nose-up (positive) wing moment, the aircraft will have static longitudinal stability. NEUTRAL POINT If you consider the CG moving rearwards from a position of static longitudinal stability: - the tail arm ‘y’ will decrease and the wing arm ‘x’ will increase; - the (negative) tail moment will decrease and the (positive) wing moment will increase. Eventually the CG will reach a position at which the tail moment is the same as the wing moment. If a vertical gust displaces the aircraft nose-up, the sum of the moments will be zero and there will be no angular acceleration about the CG to return the aircraft towards its original position of equilibrium. Because there is no resultant moment, either nose-up or nose-down, the aircraft will remain in its new position of equilibrium; the aircraft will have neutral static longitudinal stability. The position of the CG when the sum of the changes in the tail moment and wing moment caused by the gust is zero is known as the neutral point.

By convention it is positive when the relative airflow is displaced to the right of the aircraft centre-line
learning.explanation: DIRECTIONAL STATIC STABILITY The directional static stability of an aircraft is its natural tendency to recover from a disturbance in yaw, is mainly provided by the fin and involves moments about the normal axis and their relationship with yaw or sideslip angle. The sideslip angle (β) is the displacement aircraft centre-line from the relative airflow. By convention it is positive when the relative airflow is displaced to the right of the aircraft centre-line. The sideslip gives the symmetrical fin an angle of attack equal to the sideslip angle. This produces a small aerodynamic force, which, when multiplied by the distance from the centre of gravity, produces a strong restoring moment, and yaws the aircraft back to its original equilibrium position. A swept wing provides a stable contribution depending on the amount of sweepback, which increases with increase in CL (i.e. at lower IAS). This contribution is relatively weak when compared with other components. The inclination of the forward, right, wing to the relative airflow is greater than that of the rearward wing, so there is more lift and, hence, more induced drag, on the right side. The result of this discrepancy in drag on the two sides of the wing is a yawing moment to the right, which tends to eliminate the sideslip. This is a stabilizing effect, and may be important if the sweepback angle is quite large.

key_points: AERODYNAMIC DAMPING Damping is the suppression of an unwanted oscillation of a system
In an aircraft, it may be achieved manually, by an electrohydraulic system, or by aerodynamic means

learning.explanation: AERODYNAMIC DAMPING Damping is the suppression of an unwanted oscillation of a system. In an aircraft, it may be achieved manually, by an electrohydraulic system, or by aerodynamic means. This type of damping is dependent on the viscosity of the air for its success. The denser the atmosphere, the faster the unwanted movement will be extinguished When we make a control input, for instance a roll to the right, there is a resistance against this input due to "aerodynamic damping", which in this case, is where the down-going (right) wing gains an increased angle of attack as it is travelling down slightly, changing the relative airflow. This increases the lift slightly and resists the roll a little. This effect is influenced by air density, and in the low density of higher altitudes, the aircraft is travelling at a higher TAS, which means that the angle of attack change is smaller. This is a reduction in aerodynamic damping. All the control axes have natural aerodynamic damping in some form. which are reduced at high altitude. This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip

learning.explanation: DUTCH ROLL. This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip. Because of these characteristics of the Dutch roll oscillation, lateral dynamic stability has always been more of a problem than longitudinal dynamic stability. With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. With increasing altitude (decreasing density) or increasing Mach number, the possibility of a Dutch roll increases. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the likelihood of a Dutch roll. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability. Aircraft with a tendency to Dutch roll are also fitted with yaw damper. This automatically displaces the rudder proportional to the rate of yaw to damp out the oscillation. Note: Dutch roll is a result of high Lateral stability with relatively low Directional stability. Furthermore, Longitudinal stability is not a factor.

learning.explanation: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight. learning.explanation: DIHEDRAL If not corrected, an unstable aeroplane will side slip down when rolled to one side. This effect is not desirable, so how can we reduce it? By tilting the wingtips upwards, the aeroplane becomes naturally more stable in the lateral plane. This is called dihedral. Lift acts perpendicular to the relative airflow. If the aeroplane rolls to the side when disturbed by a gust of wind, the lift vector leans to the side with the aeroplane. This creates a resultant sideways facing force that makes the aeroplane side slip in the same direction. As a result of this side slip, the aeroplane is subjected to a sideways component of the relative airflow. Due to dihedral, the lower wing (into the wind) meets the upcoming airflow at a greater angle of attack than the upper wing. Consequently, the lower wing produces more lift and helps the aeroplane roll back to its original position. This is how dihedral improves lateral stability.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

key_points: An aircraft's stability affects many aspects of its flight characteristics
For an aircraft to be considered statically stable, it must initially begin to return to its original position/orientation after some sort of displacement
Think of placing a ball in a bowl, it will always begin to roll back to the bottom of the bowl, the equilibrium point
learning.explanation: An aircraft's stability affects many aspects of its flight characteristics. For an aircraft to be considered statically stable, it must initially begin to return to its original position/orientation after some sort of displacement. Think of placing a ball in a bowl, it will always begin to roll back to the bottom of the bowl, the equilibrium point. An aircraft can have stability in all three axes, pitch (longitudinal stability), yaw (directional stability) and roll (lateral stability). The opposite of stability is manoeuvrability, and if the aircraft is very stable, it is not very manoeuvrable, and vice-versa. The less stable (more manoeuvrable) we make an aircraft, the more easily it will change orientation. This is why aerobatic aircraft have very light controls, meaning that even small stick forces will cause a large aircraft movement, whereas stable aircraft, such as transport jets, are very stable, and will require much larger stick movements, and more stick force, to provide the same amount of aircraft movement. This is called stick force stability, which is a measure of how much input force is required to cause a 1G change. This question is asking about stick displacement, but it is largely the same thing. It is the reason that you would not want to cruise a highly aerobatic aircraft for long distances, as the fineness of control is difficult to achieve when the controls are so light and tiny movements cause huge changes. To answer the question, if small movements of the stick create large pitch/roll changes, the aircraft must be highly manoeuvrable. Interestingly, modern fighter aircraft, such as the Eurofighter Typhoon, are designed to be statically unstable for highest manoeuvrability, and have very responsive fly-by-wire controls making sure that the aircraft does not become unstable during flight. Excellent for air-to-air combat, terrible if they lose their FBW system.

learning.explanation: Sideslip to the right means that the aircraft is pointing forwards but going rightwards, therefore the airflow is coming from the right hand side. Another way to think of this is that on approach, the runway will be out of the right hand side window, even if there is no crosswind. Wing sweep will help increase lateral stability. When a swept-wing airplane is sideslipping, the wing toward the sideslip will experience a higher velocity normal to the wing's leading edge than the wing away from the sideslip. More lift is generated on the wing toward the sideslip and a roll moment arises that tends to diminish the bank angle or sideslip and return the airplane to equilibrium. Straighter wings are effectively longer, so produce more lift, resulting in a larger rolling moment to the left returning the aircraft to a non-sideslipped condition. This is an example of positive lateral stability.

Learning Objective 081.04.04.05.01: Describe how the following aeroplane components contribute to static directional stability: wing; fin; dorsal fin; ventral fin; angle of sweep of the wing; angle of sweep of the fin; fuselage at high alpha; strakes. The vertical stabiliser (tail fin) of an aircraft is the main contributor to static directional stability (stability in yaw), as any sideslip angle will create a lift on the fin by introducing an angle of attack to its symmetrical aerofoil, which then will create a force on the aircraft to point into the relative airflow. From here on out, we are using the words, "positive effect" (on stability) to mean that it makes the aircraft more stable. The larger we make the tail fin, the larger the positive effect (on stability). Also, the further back we make the tail fin from the centre of gravity, the larger the moment arm of the force, so the larger the positive effect. For this question, we must remember that the fin is just a wing, but when we fly coordinated (no sideslip), it is a symmetrical aerofoil, so creating no lift in either direction. Introducing a sideslip (an angle of attack - AoA) causes a lift force to be made. The greater this force, the greater the "positive effect" on stability, which pushes the tail around so the nose points towards the relative airflow. Sweepback of a wing does a few things, it increases the MCRIT of the aerofoil by making it "effectively thinner", which is very useful for high speed flight. It also changes the low speed flying characteristics a lot, decreasing the coefficient of lift for each angle of attack, but increasing the critical (stalling) angle of attack (but with a lower maximum lift output). This last bit is particularly useful for aircraft. Swept back tail fins will remain useful at higher angles of sideslip before stalling, in comparison to straight fins. Increased sweepback of the tail fin usually has a negative effect on directional stability (stability in yaw). At low/medium sideslip angles, the reduced lift coefficient for each angle of attack produces less of a restoring force (the lower gradient on the graph above). It is important to note that at higher angles of attack, within a certain range, a straight fin will have stalled (so provides almost no stability) and the swept fin would not yet have stalled due to its higher stalling AoA, and in that case, the swept fin provides far more stabilising effect than a straight fin, but only within a certain range of large sideslip angles.

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”
The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves aft, the stick force gradient decreases with decreasing maneuvering stability and the lower limit of stick force gradient may be reached. The aft limit, which for safety reasons on a transport airplane is always forward of the neutral point, is confined by insufficient stick-force stability and/or excessive in-flight maneuverability. The minimum stick force per ‘g’ for the maximum permitted load factor, which is 2.5 for large transport airplanes, determines the aft limit of the CG envelope. A CG position aft of this point would produce an unacceptably low value of maneuver stability and would make the airplane difficult to fly. For transport airplanes the aft limit is normally located at approximately 30% of the MAC.

key_points: The aircraft fin is a very powerful stabilising element of an aircraft, and contributes to positive stability both directionally (stability in yaw), and laterally (stability in roll)
Some aircraft have more complex aerodynamical needs though, leading to the use of dorsal and/or ventral fins as well as the main tail fin

Dorsal fins are effectively just an extension to the main fin, extending forwards to provide some benefits such as the blending with the fuselage, reducing drag, providing better stability at high sideslip angles, etc
learning.explanation: The aircraft fin is a very powerful stabilising element of an aircraft, and contributes to positive stability both directionally (stability in yaw), and laterally (stability in roll). Some aircraft have more complex aerodynamical needs though, leading to the use of dorsal and/or ventral fins as well as the main tail fin. Dorsal fins are effectively just an extension to the main fin, extending forwards to provide some benefits such as the blending with the fuselage, reducing drag, providing better stability at high sideslip angles, etc. They therefore have a positive effect on directional and lateral stability. Ventral fins (sometimes called strakes), however, are placed under the fuselage, and provide a further increase in directional stability (yaw), but have the opposite effect to the main and dorsal fins when it comes to lateral stability, they are de-stabilising. Ventral fins are very useful for improving the stall/spin characteristcs of aircraft where the fuselage and wings may render the main fin less effective at high angles of attack (similar to a deep stall, but for stability). Their main limitation is ground clearance. None of these items have any effect on longitudinal stability, which is stability in pitch, as a pitch change will not cause any angle of attack change to these components. Some ventral fins/strakes are actually angled outwards, so they are not perfectly vertical. Now this would give very slightly increased longitudinal stability due to their location at the rear of the aircraft, however, the majority of ventral fins (as is the primary intention of them) have no effect on longitudinal stability.

content.question:
A large jet aircraft is designed to be operated with a positive longitudinal stability and is equipped with a Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system. Prior to each flight, the pilots input the aircraft mass and CG location into the Flight Management System (FMS). The aircraft's FMS then informs the FBW system of this data, allowing for the correct control forces and limitations to be used, giving flight envelope protection and ensuring stability is maintained.
Consider what will happen to the aircraft's high altitude handling characteristics if the pilot inputs the INCORRECT CG position into the FMS, located forward of the actual CG position. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Due to the design criteria applied, the longitudinal stability of the aircraft is always ensured, irrespective of the location of the CG.
options.B: The actual longitudinal stability is lower than calculated by the FBW system, and the system may allow for control surface deflections that result in instability.
options.C: The aircraft consumes more fuel than expected during the cruise phase of the flight, as the FBW system deflects the horizontal stabiliser more to counteract the error of the pilot.
options.D: The pitch rates commanded by the FBW system are lower at higher altitudes compared to the pitch rates required to ensure that the longitudinal stability remains positive.

key_points: An aircraft's stability, and in particular its longitudinal stability (stability in pitch) is massively dependent on the location of the aircraft's Centre of Gravity (CG)
As long as the CG is in front of the "neutral point", the aircraft will be longitudinally stable
The "neutral point" is a sort of average Centre of Pressure (CP) for the whole aircraft, and it goes towards where there are more aerodynamic surfaces
learning.explanation: An aircraft's stability, and in particular its longitudinal stability (stability in pitch) is massively dependent on the location of the aircraft's Centre of Gravity (CG). As long as the CG is in front of the "neutral point", the aircraft will be longitudinally stable. The "neutral point" is a sort of average Centre of Pressure (CP) for the whole aircraft, and it goes towards where there are more aerodynamic surfaces. Think of a throwing dart, the front had a weight and the back has a set of fins, therefore a very far forward CG and a far back "neutral point". This is a very stable system. A far forward CG therefore is a more stable condition. This also means a less manoeuvrable condition. Less manoeuvrability means that the pilot will have to push and pull harder on the controls to achieve the same result, as the control surfaces need to move further to achieve the same angular change. The controls feel "heavier" with a further forward CG, but the aircraft is more stable. This can be counteracted by the Fly-By-Wire system, which uses the knowledge of the aircraft's weight and CG position to estimate the required control surface deflection, and make the controls feel the same as for any other CG position, so the pilot has the same control of the aircraft, no matter the weight or CG position. If the CG is further forwards, the FBW system will amplify the pilot's inputs more than normal in the pitch axis, to make the aircraft control as it would do "normally". This means that, in this scenario, the pilot has entered an artificially far forward CG, so the FBW system will amplify the pilot's actions in pitch, but without any need to do so, as the CG is not actually that far forward. This could lead to overcontrolling of the aircraft by the fly-by-wire system, as the aircraft is not as stable as the FMS/FBW believes. The overcontrolling could potentially reduce the stability of the aircraft, or even cause instability. As this question is easy to misread or misunderstand, we will quickly go through each option: "Due to the design criteria applied, the longitudinal stability of the aircraft is always ensured, irrespective of the location of the CG." Whilst this looks plausible, the longitudinal stability is not ensured (and will be reduced or removed) when the CG goes out of the aft limit. "The actual longitudinal stability is lower than calculated by the FBW system, and the system may allow for control surface deflections that result in instability." As mentioned above, this is correct, due to the incorrectly entered CG position, which may allow the FBW to overcontrol the aircraft. The aircraft is less stable than the FBW system believes. "The aircraft consumes more fuel than expected during the cruise phase of the flight, as the FBW system deflects the horizontal stabiliser more to counteract the error of the pilot." The aircraft will actually consume less fuel than expected, but because the aircraft expects a forward CG in the cruise, which causes the tailplane to produce more downforce, and requires more lift from the wing, causing higher drag. However, the aircraft actually has a further aft CG, so will burn less fuel than expected. This is also not connected to the FBW system creating larger deflections, that is an effect which would occur in this case, but has negligible effect on fuel consumption. "The pitch rates commanded by the FBW system are lower at higher altitudes compared to the pitch rates required to ensure that the longitudinal stability remains positive." This has nothing to do with the scenario mentioned in the question (incorrectly inputted CG location).

learning.explanation: When a manufacturer shortens the fuselage of an aircraft from 9 seats to 6 seats, the aircraft's overall dimensions and weight change. In this case, the manufacturer has increased the size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer to account for the reduced fuselage length. The larger vertical fin provides greater surface area for controlling yaw, while the larger horizontal stabilizer increases pitch stability. The larger vertical fin increases the surface area available to resist the yawing moment caused by asymmetrical thrust, crosswinds, or other factors that could cause the aircraft to turn left or right. This results in improved directional stability of the aircraft, which means that it is less likely to deviate from its intended course. Therefore, option "Positive, since the higher vertical fin." is the correct answer. The increased size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer should not reduce the effectiveness of the rudder, as the rudder is the primary control surface for yaw control. In fact, the larger surface area of the vertical fin may even enhance the rudder's effectiveness, as it provides more area for the rudder to deflect and generate a yawing moment.

content.question: An aircraft has been placed in a spiral dive. The pilot has then let go of all the controls to see how the aircraft will naturally react. Its speed, rate of turn and rate of descent all begin decreasing. What type of spiral dive mode does the aircraft possess?

options.B: Neutral.
options.C: Unstable.
options.D: Stable.

key_points: The feedback for this question was weak and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q814718 - originally seen in Austro Control), so any feedback you have about either of these questions from the real exam would be very useful to make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much
This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is almost trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing
The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability
learning.explanation: The feedback for this question was weak and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q814718 - originally seen in Austro Control), so any feedback you have about either of these questions from the real exam would be very useful to make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much. This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is almost trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing. The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability. Imagine an aircraft is disturbed to roll slightly right, and therefore takes up a slight right sideslip. The large fin yaws into the turn before the aircraft can roll out of it, and this yaw causes a further bank, which again causes more yaw before the aircraft can roll out of it. During this process, the nose keeps dropping to increase airspeed to maintain lift in the turn without any increase in angle of attack. In IMC without good use of instruments, this feels like straight and level flight until the G forces start to increase noticeably, at which point the pilot would finally notice that something was wrong, as they are in a high speed spiral dive. But now back to the theory. Many aircraft have a slight spiral instability, which, even though the aircraft might be statically stable in all axes, means that a small departure from straight and level will gradually become a spiral dive if no pilot inputs are made. As this is a gradual process, it is acceptable up to a certain rate of instability as the pilot can easily override it. Being stable in the spiral mode means that the aircraft naturally tends to reduce any spiral dives to zero. If an aircraft is stable in the spiral mode, then it is likely to have a strong tendency for dutch roll. For this question, then, if the aircraft's rate of turn, rate of descent and speed are all decreasing, then it is naturally rolling out of the turn, and is therefore stable in the spiral (dive) mode.

content.question: Why is it bad to have too much lateral stability?

options.C: More prone to Spiral dive

key_points: With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind
The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations
This is called Dutch roll
learning.explanation: With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the possibility of Dutch roll. learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. The point where the aircraft does not have any positive or negative static longitudinal stability, and therefore is static longitudinally neutral, is called the neutral point. Placing the CG aft of this point makes the aircraft unstable, placing the CG forward of this point makes the aircraft stable.

key_points: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor
When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state
The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is usually heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

A forward movement of the CG increases the positive longitudinal static stability of an aircraft but decreases the manoeuvrability and control response because the moment arm is increased in length and increases the nose-down pitching moment. Thus, the elevators have less nose-up authority. The aeroplane with positive manoeuvring stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. When the aeroplane has high static stability, the manoeuvring stability will be high and a high stick force gradient will result. learning.explanation: SPIRAL INSTABILITY Spiral instability occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is strong and the lateral stability is weak. When a wing drops, due to a disturbance, the tendency of the aeroplane to correct this departure from the balanced condition in level flight is dependent on the lateral stability of the aeroplane. Additionally, when a wing drops, it causes other secondary motions to be initiated. The fin and rudder tend to yaw the aeroplane into the airflow in the direction of the dropped wing. Because of the yaw, the higher wing on the outside of the turn is travelling faster than the lower wing and develops a greater amount of lift. This generates a rolling moment in the opposite direction to the correcting moment of the dihedral and if the rolling moment is greater it will tend to increase the angle of bank. If the rolling moment is of sufficient magnitude to overcome the correcting force, produced by the dihedral and the damping yaw effect, the bank angle will increase and the aeroplane will enter a steadily steepening spiral dive. This is spiral instability that can be described as a combined lateral and directional aperiodic motion.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed. In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state. An aircraft's type of static stability is defined by its initial reaction after some external force is removed. We use the term "static" because we're only concerned with the initial tendency to return to equilibrium, without considering subsequent motion. Manoeuvrability, on the other hand, is the aircraft's ability to change its position or attitude in response to pilot inputs, allowing it to perform various manoeuvres. Stability and manoeuvrability are effectively opposite, and the greater an aircraft's stability, the lower the manoeuvrability, and vice-versa. An aircraft with a further forward CG has greater stability (but lower manoeuvrability) and aircraft with aft CG locations have lower stability, but higher manoeuvrability. Higher weight also tends to reduce manoeuvrability, but this rule isn't always as simple as the CG locations. The question tells us that stability is affected by the CG location and the gross weight of the aircraft, and, knowing that manoeuvrability and stability are closely (and inversely) linked, that hints to us that those factors also affect the manoeuvrability, which they do. That removes the following options: "cannot be affected by the pilot or operator as it is determined by the aircraft design.", as the CG location and weight can be affected by the operator/pilot, so therefore, the manoeuvrability can be too; and "is determined by the size of the control surfaces only, not the CG position or the weight.", as the manoeuvrability is changed by the CG location and weight. The other options can be chosen between based on the CG location and weight, and the effects of those mentioned above.

options.B: It is an oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state with small changes of speed and height.

options.D: It is an oscillatory motion of the airplane in yaw after a disturbance to its trimmed state with no variations of speed.

key_points: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor
When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state
The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is normally heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

learning.explanation: An aircraft is said to be trimmed (in trim) if all moments in pitch, roll, and yaw are equal to zero. The term controllability refers to the ability of the aircraft to respond to control surface displacement and achieve the desired condition of flight. Adequate controllability must be available to perform take-off and landing and accomplish the various maneuvers in flight. A contradiction exists between stability and controllability. A high degree of stability gives reduced controllability. The relationship between static stability and controllability is demonstrated by figure 1 and 2. The effect of increased static stability (forward CG movement) on controllability is illustrated by the ball in a steeper trough (figure 2). A greater force is required to “control” the ball to the same position of displacement when the static stability is increased. In this manner, a large degree of static stability tends to make the aircraft less controllable. It is necessary to achieve the proper proportion between static stability and controllability during the design of an aircraft because too much static stability (forward CG position) reduces controllability. The forward CG limit is set to ensure minimum controllability.

key_points: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane
Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left
Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip
learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. The airplane design features that increase the lateral static stability are: dihedral. sweepback. high-wing mounting. increased effective dihedral. large, high vertical fin. low CG. The airplane design features that decrease the lateral static stability are: anhedral. forward-swept wings. ventral fin. low-wing mounting. extending inboard flaps.

content.question: When an aircraft enters a spiral dive with the CG at the AFT limit, when the spiral dive is fully developed, which of the following pitch attitudes is most likely?

options.A: Nose Up
options.B: Nose Down
options.C: Nose Level
options.D: Impossible to determine

key_points: Note: This is a completely different scenario to the similar questions that exist about spins
A spiral dive occurs when an aircraft is very directionally stable (stable in yaw) and not very laterally stable (stable in roll)

When a significant sideslip is induced, a stable aircraft will want to yaw very towards the oncoming airflow direction, and in a balanced aircraft, would also roll away from the oncoming airflow direction
learning.explanation: Note: This is a completely different scenario to the similar questions that exist about spins. A spiral dive occurs when an aircraft is very directionally stable (stable in yaw) and not very laterally stable (stable in roll). When a significant sideslip is induced, a stable aircraft will want to yaw very towards the oncoming airflow direction, and in a balanced aircraft, would also roll away from the oncoming airflow direction. However, the aircraft's roll would not be as strong in this scenario, and the strong yawing effect may even overpower it, which would cause the aircraft to yaw and roll towards the oncoming airflow. This intense yawing effect basically overpowers the other aspects of stability and makes the aircraft bank in the same direction, which forms a spiral dive. Spiral dives can make the aircraft speed up very quickly and can cause overspeed or overstress if not dealt with quickly, as they get worse with time. Spiral dives are referred to as "aperiodic" motion as they do not go back and forth (like dutch roll), they only happen once, getting further from equilibrium. The key part of this question is that spiral dives are always pointing downwards, as they are a dive. If the nose was upwards, they would be a stall/spin. Note that you can easily create an accelerated stall leading to a spin from a spiral dive, if handled incorrectly.

learning.explanation: The rotation of an aircraft about its normal, or vertical, axis is a yaw. If this movement is the result of an undesirable disturbance, then the ability of the airplane to return to its original heading without the assistance of any control-surface movement is a measure of its directional static stability. It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow. Sideslip is the displacement angle of the airplane’s longitudinal axis (plane of symmetry) in azimuth from the relative airflow (speed vector). It is positive when the relative airflow is to the right of the longitudinal axis and negative when the relative airflow is left of the longitudinal axis. An airplane has directional static stability if, when in a sideslip with the airflow coming from the left initially the nose tends to yaw left. An airplane that has excessive directional static stability compared to its lateral static stability is more prone to spiral dive.

learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin. The camber of an airfoil can be increased with the use of flaps. The end of the wing reaches out and/or downwards, changing the side profile of the wing and moving the CP aft, resulting in a nose down pitching moment. This generates a higher value of CL at the same Angle of Attack. Therefore if flaps are being retracted, the Angle of Attack should be increased.

key_points: When density altitude decreases, the air gets "thicker", meaning that there are more air particles per cubic metre, and therefore more air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would increase lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude decreases, the air gets "thicker", meaning that there are more air particles per cubic metre, and therefore more air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would increase lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but descend in the atmosphere, the higher air density means that we have to fly slower to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is a decrease in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with decreased altitude. As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with a decrease in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the left, due to the decreased TAS for the same IAS at lower altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 2, moving to the left.

content.question: How are the angle of attack and the margin to the stall affected by the extension of spoilers?

options.A: Angle of attack increases: margin to stall increases.
options.B: Angle of attack increases; margin to stall reduces.
options.C: Angle of attack decreases; margin to stall increases.
options.D: Angle of attack is unaffected; margin to stall is unaffected.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The feedback for this question is old and has not been verified for over a year

Given other questions in the database which have been confirmed, we have decided to change the options to make one "actually correct", rather than the very questionable previous options, which were never fully verified
This question could have even been removed from EASA's database by now, but we also cannot guarantee that
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The feedback for this question is old and has not been verified for over a year. Given other questions in the database which have been confirmed, we have decided to change the options to make one "actually correct", rather than the very questionable previous options, which were never fully verified. This question could have even been removed from EASA's database by now, but we also cannot guarantee that. Please let us know in the comments if you see this question in the real exam, and anything you can remember from it. BACKGROUND INFORMATION Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect of spoilers on the critical angle of attack is much more complex (and explained where necessary in different questions), and unpredictable, but EASA appear to say that it increases with spoiler deployment (opposite to how it decreases when trailing edge flaps are deployed). As far as we are aware, it could actually increase or decrease slightly in real life, dependent on the wing, spoiler size and location, and particularly the amount of spoiler extension. For this question though, mercifully, the answer remains the same. ANSWERING THE QUESTION The question asks about the angle of attack of the wing. When spoilers are extended, the lift decreases, so without any change to the angle of attack, then the aircraft will no longer be in equilibrium, so in reality, to counteract weight, the angle of attack of the wing has to increase. This agrees with our experience of flying jets, in when we extend spoilers, the aircraft pitches up slightly. The margin to the stall is a very vague term, as it could mean the difference between current speed and stall speed, but it is more likely to mean in terms of angle of attack, and in this case, would probably be the difference between the aircraft's current angle of attack and the critical angle of attack (AoA). When spoilers are extended, the actual AoA is forced to increase to maintain the flight path, and the critical angle of attack will either decrease slightly (according to some other sources) or increase slightly (according to EASA's other questions), but either way, the increase in current AoA will likely be much greater, so the margin to stall will decrease.

learning.explanation: When an aircraft flies close to the ground, the downwash of air causing induced drag has nowhere to go, it is stopped by the fixed ground beneath. Therefore, being close to the ground decreases downwash and decreases induced drag. This is called ground effect. Ground effect increases as an aircraft flies closer to the ground, so the lowest height would give the lowest induced drag. Obviously then, the highest induced drag would occur when at the greatest height above the ground. Ground effect is usually cited as taking effect at approximately half the wingspan of height (which would be 30 ft here), as that is when it becomes significant and noticeable, but as with everything in aerodynamics, it is not a binary effect (on or off), it is a gradual change, so the correct answer here is simply the greatest height.

CL = the Coefficient of Lift, or the product of aerofoil design (shape) and angle of attack, or relative pressure distribution. In other words, its ability to deflect air, so this can vary between aerofoils. The coefficient will be maximum at, or just before, the stall, which you can see from the formula - if CL increases on one side, the other side (L) will also increase, until lift can no longer be produced. Similarly, reducing speed (V) decreases lift. Thus, to keep the same lift, you must change the angle of attack (CL) if you change speed, and vice versa.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. As an airfoil (wing) moves through the air, varying changes in velocity occur on its surfaces. Air particles move around it in specific trajectories. These trajectories are called streamlines. Diverging streamlines mean a decrease in airspeed. Converging streamlines imply an increase in airspeed. In Conclusion: With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). If dynamic pressure decreases, static pressure increases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

options.D: V

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V2) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

key_points: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons
They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift
(If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions)
learning.explanation: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the lift of the wing greatly, with an unknown effect on the critical AoA Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but it appears that EASA have published other questions where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here. A big consideration for this question is the scenario. We are at the critical AoA and we raise the speedbrakes. Of course, we will begin to descend as the drag increases, unless we add thrust. if we don't do either of these things then the aircraft will quickly stall, but initially, assuming the angle of attack remains constant, the speedbrake extension should slightly delay the stall to a higher AoA.

learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). content.question: Which statement concerning the local flow pattern around a wing is correct?

options.A: By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wing tip vortices is reduced which in turn reduces induced drag.
options.B: Slat extension, at a constant angle of attack and normal extension speeds, will increase the lift coefficient, which will also increase the induced drag coefficient.
options.C: Sweepback reduces drag since, compared with a straight wing of equal area, the span increases.
options.D: Vortex generators on the wing partially block the spanwise flow over the wing leading to a reduction in induced drag.

key_points: "By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wingtip vortices is reduced, which in turn reduces induced drag
" Correct
Winglets are small vertical aerofoils that are integrated into the wingtip
learning.explanation: "By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wingtip vortices is reduced, which in turn reduces induced drag." Correct. Winglets are small vertical aerofoils that are integrated into the wingtip. These generate a slight forward force and disrupt the airflow from the lower to the upper surface of the wing, diminishing the intensity of the wingtip vortex. Both effects contribute to a reduction in induced drag. Let's examine the remaining options and discuss why they are incorrect: "Slat extension, at a constant angle of attack and normal extension speeds, will increase the lift coefficient, which will also increase the induced drag coefficient." Incorrect. At a constant aircraft angle of attack, the extension of slats decreases the angle of attack on the specific wing section, preventing an increase in the lift coefficient (CL). The advantage of slats becomes evident when the aircraft's angle of attack is subsequently increased. "Sweepback reduces drag since, compared with a straight wing of equal area, the span increases." Incorrect. Sweepback actually reduces the wingspan, thereby lowering the aspect ratio and increasing induced drag. "Vortex generators on the wing partially block the spanwise flow over the wing, leading to a reduction in induced drag." Incorrect. Vortex generators are designed to energize the boundary layer, but they typically contribute to increased drag rather than inducing a reduction in induced drag.

key_points: A venturi works on the principle of pressure, speed and airflow
Air comes in under constant pressure (which we will call X from this point onwards) and is directed through the tube
At a certain point in time, the tube starts becoming tighter
learning.explanation: A venturi works on the principle of pressure, speed and airflow. Air comes in under constant pressure (which we will call X from this point onwards) and is directed through the tube. At a certain point in time, the tube starts becoming tighter. However, the same amount of air still has to travel through this (now tighter) tube (we call this airflow Y). It does so by flowing faster than before. This increased airspeed creates a lower pressure at the tighter part of the venturi, while the wider part still has its original pressure and airspeed. After the tightening, the tube becomes wider again and the air returns to its original static pressure and airspeed (airflow Z). It now has the properties of airflow X again. Before the venturi (airflow X) Static Pressure normal Speed of the airflow normal In the throat (airflow Y) Total pressure same as airflow X and Z Static Pressure low Speed of the airflow increased After the venturi (airflow Z) Static Pressure normal Speed of the airflow normal The venturi works on Bernoulli’s principle. Bernoulli’s principle states that in increase in speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in the fluid’s static pressure. The formula for this principle = Total pressure = static pressure + dynamic pressure. If airspeed increases, the static pressure decreases and dynamic pressure increases, keeping total pressure the same.

learning.explanation: The lift curve, depicted as CL-α, illustrates the lift coefficient (CL) relative to the angle of attack (α) for an aerofoil section. The section is symmetrical because no lift is produced at zero angle of attack. This graphical representation serves as a useful tool for understanding different aircraft configurations. As the angle of attack increases, the lift coefficient rises until reaching its maximum value (CLMAX), corresponding to the critical angle of attack. To generate a constant lift force, any change in dynamic pressure must be accompanied by a change in angle of attack as long as CL is less than CLMAX. CL greater than CLMAX is not possible. The zero angle of attack condition is represented by the intersection with the vertical axis, where α equals 0. CLMAX denotes the maximum achievable CL, positioned at the graph's peak.

learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than half the length of its wingspan, the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag, and of course, the low mounted wings are more greatly affected by this, due to their location close to the surface. This phenomenon is called ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the presence of the nearby ground alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices and reduces the strength of downwash. Aircraft entering ground effect: Lift increases (if AoA remains constant) The effective angle of attack (αe) increases. The induced angle of attack (αi) decreases. Induced drag decreases. Downwash decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: Lift decreases (if AoA remains constant). The effective angle of attack (αe) decreases. The induced angle of attack (αi) increases. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. Therefore, the lift decreases when leaving ground effect, and this is more prominent on a low-wing aeroplane where the wings are naturally much closer to the ground.

Therefore, we have used our experience with the authorities to give our "best guess" of their correct answer.
